svg.title: Singer's Principle for Preventing Bad Occurrences
svg.desc: An interactive (use the Tab key) exploration of philosopher Peter Singer's principle for preventing bad occurrences. The principle is from Peter Singer's paper "Famine, Affluence, and Morality" in Philosophy and Public Affairs Vol 1. No. 3 (Spring 1972): 229-43.

cc:Work.dc:title: Singer's Principle for Preventing Bad Occurrences
cc:Work.dc:description: An interactive (use the Tab key) exploration of philosopher Peter Singer's principle for preventing bad occurrences.

text.tspan: Singer's Principle for Preventing Bad Occurrences

tspan.tspan: "If it is in our power to prevent something bad from

text.tspan: happening, without thereby sacrificing anything of
comparable moral importance, we ought, morally,
to do it."
Criticisms: Principle Analogy
Philosopher Peter Singer uses this principle in his paper "Famine, Affluence, and
Morality" from Philosophy and Public Affairs in 1971. He applies the principle to
the imaginary case of a single child drowning in a shallow pond; a typical passerby
should rescue the child because she has the power to do so without sacrificing
anything comparable in moral importance to the life of the child. Analogously, the
affluent should be giving much more to famine relief than they currently do.
The principle is universal rather than particular, thus
applying to anyone, at any time, in any place. The
principle is also general rather than specific, for it has
no restrictions as to circumstances. So 'our' and 'we'
could refer to an individual, a group, or any moral agent.
The idea here is that the moral agent can
perform some action(s) that will have as a
consequence the prevention of the bad
occurrence. Thus the passerby in the pond
example can wade in and pull the child out.
Similarly, the affluent can donate money to
famine relief efforts, thus using this means to
save some people from starvation.
In the pond analogy, the 'something bad'
is the death of the child by drowning. In
the famine case, it is 'suffering and death
from lack of food, shelter, and medical
care'. In later work such as Practical Ethics,
Singer identifies absolute poverty as the
bad to be prevented.
The 'thereby' most generally refers
to anything associated with the
prevention of the bad occurrence.
So, more specifically, it refers to
the action(s) undertaken by the
moral agent and to any and all
consequences of that action.
In preventing the bad occurrence, there
is likely to be a loss or sacrifice of some
kind. In the pond analogy, the passerby
sacrifices her shoes, time, and perhaps
some activity she was planning to do later
in the day. In the famine case, the affluent
must do without what they instead could
have bought with the donated money.
Singer does not specify exactly what he means by this phrase. But he does say that
'without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance' means 'without
causing anything else comparably bad to happen, or doing something that is wrong
in itself, or failing to promote some moral good, comparable in significance to the
bad thing that we can prevent'. By leaving it unanalyzed, he wants to ensure that the
principle is uncontroversial and
compatible with a wide range of
rival normative ethical theories.
The principle purports to be a moral or practical principle
and not a prudential principle that serves merely to advance
the interests of the agent. As such, the principle morally
prescribes that the moral agent should, assuming the given
conditions (e.g., agent has the power; nothing of comparable
moral importance is sacrificed) are satisfied, perform some
action(s) that will keep the bad occurrence from happening.
The 'it' refers to the action (or actions)
that will prevent the bad occurrence.
The analogy between the pond example and the real-world famine relief case has been
criticized at many points. The most common disanalogies are perhaps these: physical
distance, community membership, rarity of occurrence, number of victims, degree of
success, identifiability of victims, diffusion of responsibility, breadth of consequences,
and knowledge of effectiveness. There has been much discussion in the philosophical
literature as to whether any of these points of disanalogy justifies a moral difference in
how the moral agent should respond in the two situations. Singer maintains that none
of the disanalogies carries sufficient weight or relevance to justify the moral agent in
changing her response from rescue to apathy.
The principle itself, as opposed to the argument that uses it, can be criticized on several
fronts. First, it has been maintained that the principle is too demanding; the moral saint
may be able to comply with its demands, but the typical person, unable to pursue any
of her personal projects, will be crushed under their weight. Second, the principle has
very limited application, for its conditions are rarely met. For example, diverting our
money from the purchase of unneeded consumer items to donations to famine relief
causes a loss of income to those people involved in the manufacture, distribution, and
sale of those consumer items, and this reduced income can in turn cause something
comparably bad to happen: no (next) meal, shot, or bednet.
